Package Huffman

Class CanonicalCode

  • java.lang.Object
    • Huffman.CanonicalCode

  • public final class CanonicalCode
extends java.lang.Object
    A canonical Huffman code, which only describes the code length of each symbol. Immutable. Code length 0 means no code for the symbol.

    The binary codes for each symbol can be reconstructed from the length information. In this implementation, lexicographically lower binary codes are assigned to symbols with lower code lengths, breaking ties by lower symbol values. For example:

      Code lengths (canonical code):
    Symbol A: 1
    Symbol B: 3
    Symbol C: 0 (no code)
    Symbol D: 2
    Symbol E: 3
  
  Sorted lengths and symbols:
    Symbol A: 1
    Symbol D: 2
    Symbol B: 3
    Symbol E: 3
    Symbol C: 0 (no code)
  
  Generated Huffman codes:
    Symbol A: 0
    Symbol D: 10
    Symbol B: 110
    Symbol E: 111
    Symbol C: None
  
  Huffman codes sorted by symbol:
    Symbol A: 0
    Symbol B: 110
    Symbol C: None
    Symbol D: 10
    Symbol E: 111
    See Also:
    CodeTree

    • Constructor Detail

      • CanonicalCode

        public CanonicalCode​(int[] codeLens)
        Constructs a canonical Huffman code from the specified array of symbol code lengths. Each code length must be non-negative. Code length 0 means no code for the symbol. The collection of code lengths must represent a proper full Huffman code tree.

        Examples of code lengths that result in under-full Huffman code trees:

        • [1]
        • [3, 0, 3]
        • [1, 2, 3]

        Examples of code lengths that result in correct full Huffman code trees:

        • [1, 1]
        • [2, 2, 1, 0, 0, 0]
        • [3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3]

        Examples of code lengths that result in over-full Huffman code trees:

        • [1, 1, 1]
        • [1, 1, 2, 2, 3, 3, 3, 3]
        Parameters:
        codeLens - array of symbol code lengths
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the array is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the array length is less than 2, any element is negative, or the collection of code lengths would yield an under-full or over-full Huffman code tree

      • CanonicalCode

        public CanonicalCode​(CodeTree tree,
                     int symbolLimit)
        Builds a canonical Huffman code from the specified code tree.
        Parameters:
        tree - the code tree to analyze
        symbolLimit - a number greater than the maximum symbol value in the tree
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the tree is null
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the symbol limit is less than 2, or a leaf node in the tree has symbol value greater or equal to the symbol limit

    • Method Detail

      • getSymbolLimit

        public int getSymbolLimit​()
        Returns the symbol limit for this canonical Huffman code. Thus this code covers symbol values from 0 to symbolLimit−1.
        Returns:
        the symbol limit, which is at least 2

      • getCodeLength

        public int getCodeLength​(int symbol)
        Returns the code length of the specified symbol value. The result is 0 if the symbol has node code; otherwise the result is a positive number.
        Parameters:
        symbol - the symbol value to query
        Returns:
        the code length of the symbol, which is non-negative
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the symbol is out of range

      • toCodeTree

        public CodeTree toCodeTree​()
        Returns the canonical code tree for this canonical Huffman code.
        Returns:
        the canonical code tree
